12.summary: This verse, as Allama Tabatabai notes in Al-Mizan, expands on this by linking the verse to the ontological relationship between human deeds and their recompense. In Surah At-Takwir, verse 12 describes a pivotal moment in the cosmic upheaval of the Day of Judgment: "And when Hellfire (al-jahim) is set ablaze (su''irat). " This verse, revealed during the Meccan period, forms part of a series of vivid depictions of the end times aimed at awakening the Quraysh’s consciousness to divine accountability. The term *al-jahim* refers specifically to a blazing level of Hell, distinguished by its intense heat, while *su''irat* derives from the root *sa’ara* (to ignite), emphasizing the deliberate stoking of Hell’s flames as a prepared punishment for those who rejected truth and oppressed others. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) taught that the "ignition" of Hell is not merely a physical phenomenon but a manifestation of humanity’s accumulated spiritual corruption. By internalizing the reality of accountability, Muslims can navigate modern challenges with humility, justice, and a consciousness of eternity.

13.layer1:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 13, Allah declares, *"Wa idhal-jannatu uzlifat"* (And when Paradise is brought near), painting a vivid image of the Day of Judgment. This verse forms part of a sequence describing cosmic transformations—stars dimming, mountains moving—that signal the collapse of the worldly order. The term *jannah* (Paradise) here refers not merely to a physical garden but to the ultimate divine reward, while *uzlifat* (brought near) derives from the root *z-l-f*, meaning proximity or accessibility. In this context, it signifies Paradise being made immediately attainable to the righteous, transcending earthly barriers of time and space.  

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasises that this "nearness" reflects the collapse of illusions separating humans from divine truth. The verse, revealed in Mecca during intense persecution of early Muslims, reassured believers that transient suffering would yield to eternal justice. Scholars like Shaykh Tabarsi note that such verses aimed to awaken humanity to accountability, urging them to align their actions with divine will.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse is a powerful reminder of life’s transient nature and the permanence of the hereafter. The "bringing near" of Paradise challenges us to view our daily choices—acts of worship, ethical conduct, and compassion—as direct investments in our eternal proximity to Allah. It also echoes Shia teachings on the role of the Ahlul Bayt as guides who illuminate the path to this nearness. By embodying Quranic values and the wisdom of Imam Ali and his descendants, believers cultivate a spiritual readiness to embrace Paradise when it is unveiled. Practically, this means prioritising sincerity in worship, justice in dealings, and humility in seeking nearness to Allah, ensuring our lives become a reflection of the eternal garden we hope to inhabit.
13.layer2:
In Surah al-Takwir’s thirteenth verse, the phrase “when Paradise is brought near” (wa-idhā al-jannatu uzlifat) is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as a profound eschatological event signifying both the immediacy of divine recompense and the ontological transformation of existence on the Day of Resurrection. Drawing from the works of Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, Shia exegesis emphasizes that the “bringing near” (izlaf) of Paradise transcends mere spatial proximity, instead symbolizing the unveiling of eternal realities to souls according to their spiritual capacity and preparedness. Tabrisi notes that this izlaf reflects divine mercy, as Paradise is “made accessible” to the righteous through their alignment with truth (haqq) during their earthly lives, a concept rooted in the Quranic principle that deeds are rendered proximate to Allah (5:35).

Tabatabai expands this metaphysically, arguing that Paradise’s nearness signifies the soul’s existential readiness to perceive and inhabit the higher realms of being, as the veils of material existence are lifted. This aligns with the Shia theological emphasis on the intrinsic connection between human agency, divine grace, and the intercession (shafa’ah) of the Ahl al-Bayt, who are regarded as the “gateways to Paradise” (abwab al-rahmah) in hadith literature. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in *Bihar al-Anwar*, teaches that recognition (ma’rifah) of the Imams enables believers to “see Paradise before entering it,” underscoring the Shia doctrine that spiritual authority (wilayah) is the axis of salvation.

The verse also integrates with broader Islamic eschatology, where the juxtaposition of Paradise’s nearness and Hell’s approach (cf. 81:12) illustrates the dual outcomes of divine justice. Shia jurisprudence links this to the ethical imperative of enjoining good and forbidding evil (al-amr bi’l-ma’ruf), as earthly actions directly shape one’s posthumous reality. Thus, the verse encapsulates the Shia worldview where cosmic events are inseparable from moral and theological truths, mediated through the guidance of the infallible Imams.
13.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Takwir’s depiction of Paradise being “brought near” is often interpreted as a dynamic interplay between divine promise and human responsibility. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that this verse transcends mere eschatology: it invites believers to recognize Paradise not as a distant abstraction but as a reality shaped by ethical choices in the present. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this proximity to the Quranic concept of *qurb* (nearness to God), suggesting that spiritual refinement and social justice efforts “draw closer” the divine presence inherent in Paradise’s blessings.  

Scientifically, the imagery resonates with quantum theories of multidimensionality, where Paradise might exist beyond our temporal plane—a concept echoed by thinkers like Dr. Mehdi Golshani, who bridges Islamic theology and physics. Philosophically, the verse challenges materialist worldviews by affirming transcendent realities accessible through faith and virtue.  

Socially, this verse inspires activism. Scholars such as Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani link “bringing Paradise near” to addressing crises like climate change and inequality, framing environmental stewardship and poverty alleviation as acts of *taqwa* (God-consciousness) that mirror celestial harmony. In multicultural contexts, the theme parallels Buddhist “Pure Land” aspirations and Christian notions of the Kingdom of Heaven, fostering interfaith solidarity in pursuing shared ethical goals.  

Amid global alienation and ecological collapse, this verse becomes a call to action: Paradise is not passively awaited but actively approximated through compassion, justice, and reverence for creation—a timeless vision reimagined for modern struggles.
13.layer4:
erse "And when Paradise is brought near" (81:13) transcends its apparent meaning of the Hereafter’s events. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate this as a spiritual reality tied to the recognition of divine guardianship (*Wilayah*). Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, “Paradise is brought near to the hearts of the believers when they recognize their Imam, for the Imam is the gate to Allah and the path to His pleasure” (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Here, Paradise symbolizes the nearness to Allah’s mercy, attainable through unwavering connection to the Imams, who are the manifest signs of His guidance.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that Paradise is “the reward for those who love us [Ahlul Bayt] and walk upon our path” (*Bihar al-Anwar*). This love is not passive; it demands embodying the virtues of the Infallibles—justice, humility, and devotion. The “nearness” of Paradise thus reflects the soul’s proximity to divine light through adherence to their teachings.  

Imam Ali (peace be upon him) explains in *Nahj al-Balagha*: “The believer’s Paradise is in their heart, a garden watered by faith.” This inner Paradise blossoms through acts of worship, sincerity, and ethical conduct rooted in the awareness of the Imam’s presence. To experience this nearness, one must cultivate *ma’rifah* (divine recognition) of the Imam’s role as the spiritual axis of creation.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to align their lives with the Imams’ legacy. Daily recitation of *Ziyarat Ashura*, seeking forgiveness at dawn (*tahajjud*), and serving creation as Imam Hussain (peace be upon him) exemplified are means to “bring Paradise near.” By anchoring the heart in the love of the Ahlul Bayt, the veils of heedlessness lift, allowing the soul to taste the eternal Gardens in this very life.

سائنسی طور پر ، منظر کشی کثیر جہتی کے کوانٹم نظریات کے ساتھ گونجتی ہے ، جہاں ہمارے دنیاوی طیارے سے باہر جنت موجود ہوسکتی ہے۔ یہ ایک تصور ڈاکٹر مہدی گولشانی جیسے مفکرین کے ذریعہ گونجتا ہے ، جو اسلامی الہیات اور طبیعیات کو پُر کرتے ہیں۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، آیت مادیت پسند دنیا کے نظارے کو چیلنجوں اور فضیلت کے ذریعہ قابل رسائی حقائق کی تصدیق کرکے چیلنج کرتی ہے۔

لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن) نے سکھایا کہ جنت "ان لوگوں کے لئے انعام ہے جو ہم سے محبت کرتے ہیں [اہل بیت] اور ہمارے راستے پر چلتے ہیں" (*بہار الانور*)۔ یہ محبت غیر فعال نہیں ہے۔ اس کا مطالبہ ہے کہ انفالبلز کی خوبیوں کو مجسم بنائیں - انصاف ، عاجزی اور عقیدت۔ اس طرح جنت کی "قربت" ان کی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہونے کے ذریعہ روح کی الہی روشنی سے قربت کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔  

امام علی (اس پر سلامتی ہے) *ناہج البالاگھا *میں وضاحت کرتے ہیں: "مومن کی جنت ان کے دل میں ہے ، ایک باغ جو ایمان سے پانی پلایا جاتا ہے۔" یہ داخلی جنت پوجا ، اخلاص اور اخلاقی طرز عمل کے ذریعہ کھلتی ہے جو امام کی موجودگی کے بارے میں شعور میں شامل ہے۔ اس قربت کا تجربہ کرنے کے ل one ، کسی کو تخلیق کے روحانی محور کے طور پر امام کے کردار کی * ما ra یفاہ * (الہی پہچان) کاشت کرنا ہوگا۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو اپنی زندگی کو اماموں کی میراث سے ہم آہنگ کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ روزانہ*زیارت آشورا*کی تلاوت ، صبح (*طاہجود*) کے وقت معافی مانگنے ، اور امام حسین (اس پر سلامتی) کے طور پر تخلیق کی خدمت کرنا "جنت کو قریب لانے" کا مطلب ہے۔ احلول بیت کی محبت میں دل کو لنگر انداز کرکے ، لاپرواہ لفٹ کے پردے ، روح کو اسی زندگی میں ابدی باغات کا مزہ چکھنے دیتے ہیں۔
13.layer5:
In examining Surah At-Takwir 81:13, both Shia and Sunni exegetes concur that the verse depicts eschatological realities, specifically the drawing near of Paradise on the Day of Judgment as a manifestation of divine mercy and recompense for the righteous. Classical sources such as Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* emphasize the literal understanding of Paradise being physically “brought near” (uzlifat), underscoring Allah’s omnipotence in altering cosmic realities. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* similarly highlight the thematic link to resurrection scenes in adjacent verses, framing this proximity as a moment of hope for believers.  

Divergences emerge in theological nuances. Shia commentaries like Qummi’s tafsir and Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* often contextualize this “nearness” within the framework of the Ahl al-Bayt’s intercession, interpreting Paradise’s approach as inseparable from the spiritual mediation of the Imams. This reflects the Shia emphasis on *walayah* (divine guardianship) as a conduit for salvation. Sunni scholars such as Qurtubi and Razi, while acknowledging divine mercy, prioritize individual accountability, with Razi’s *Mafatih al-Ghayb* framing the verse as a direct divine act unmediated by human intercessors.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Shia thought integrates Imamology into eschatology, whereas Sunni exegesis often centers divine agency and individual responsibility. While both traditions affirm Paradise’s reality and divine justice, the Shia emphasis on the Ahl al-Bayt’s role reflects historical developments in Imami theology post-Prophetic succession debates. Practically, this influences devotional focus in Shia spirituality on seeking the Imams’ intercession, contrasting with Sunni prioritization of personal piety. Both interpretations, however, ultimately reinforce core Islamic eschatological beliefs without contradicting the verse’s apparent meaning.

13.summary: Drawing from Al-Mizan, Allama Tabatabai explains that In Tafsir al-Mizan, Allama Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, Shia exegesis emphasizes that the “bringing near” (izlaf) of Paradise transcends mere spatial proximity, instead symbolizing the unveiling of eternal realities to souls according to their spiritual capacity and preparedness. In Surah At-Takwir, verse 13, Allah declares, *"Wa idhal-jannatu uzlifat"* (And when Paradise is brought near), painting a vivid image of the Day of Judgment. This verse forms part of a sequence describing cosmic transformations—stars dimming, mountains moving—that signal the collapse of the worldly order. The term *jannah* (Paradise) here refers not merely to a physical garden but to the ultimate divine reward, while *uzlifat* (brought near) derives from the root *z-l-f*, meaning proximity or accessibility. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, “Paradise is brought near to the hearts of the believers when they recognize their Imam, for the Imam is the gate to Allah and the path to His pleasure” (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Practically, this means prioritising sincerity in worship, justice in dealings, and humility in seeking nearness to Allah, ensuring our lives become a reflection of the eternal garden we hope to inhabit.

14.layer1:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 14 – *عَلِمَتْ نَفْسٌۭ مَّآ أَحْضَرَتْ* – Allah describes a profound moment on the Day of Judgment when every soul will fully comprehend the consequences of its earthly life. The phrase *"ma ahdarat"* (what it has brought) refers to the deeds, intentions, and spiritual state each individual carries into the hereafter. Shia tafsir, as emphasized by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, explains that this "bringing forth" isn’t limited to physical actions but includes the hidden realities of one’s soul – the sincerity of worship, moral choices, and even unspoken truths that define one’s relationship with Allah. The word *nafs* (soul/self) here underscores individual accountability, rejecting the notion of collective salvation or blame.

Revealed in Mecca during intense persecution of early Muslims, this verse reassured believers that ultimate justice lies with Allah. It countered the arrogance of Quraysh leaders who dismissed resurrection, affirming that no power or status can shield one from divine reckoning. The term *ahdarat* derives from *hadara* (to attend/present), implying that deeds aren’t merely recorded but actively accompany the soul, becoming inseparable from its identity.

For modern Muslims, this verse is a timeless call to self-awareness. It reminds us that our choices – from daily interactions to lifelong goals – are eternal investments. In an age of distraction, it challenges us to ask: What am I "bringing" to my meeting with Allah? Practical application lies in regular *muhasaba* (self-assessment), aligning actions with Quranic values, and nurturing virtues like honesty, compassion, and humility. As Imam Ali (AS) taught, "The Day of Judgment is already present in your awareness of it" – a truth that transforms how we live today.
14.layer2:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 14 emerges within a vivid depiction of eschatological upheaval, where cosmic order collapses and human accountability is laid bare. The phrase *"a soul will know what it has brought"* is interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as encapsulating the soul’s inescapable confrontation with its accumulated deeds on the Day of Judgment. Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, elucidates that *"what it has brought"* (ma ahdarat) refers to the entirety of one’s actions, both manifest and concealed, which are indelibly recorded and presented to the soul. This "bringing forth" signifies not merely a recollection but an existential unveiling, where deeds become tangibly present before the soul, stripping away all self-deception or external blame.

Allamah Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes the ontological transformation in human perception on that Day: the soul’s limited earthly awareness is replaced by a divinely illuminated consciousness (*ma’rifah haqqah*), enabling it to comprehend the true weight of its choices. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that divine justice (*‘adl*) necessitates absolute transparency in reckoning, where no soul bears another’s burden (Q 6:164). The verse also resonates with the Shia understanding of *walayah* (divinely ordained allegiance), as deeds are ultimately judged in relation to one’s recognition and adherence to the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, the spiritual heirs of prophetic authority.

Scholars like Al-Fayd al-Kashani link this verse to the doctrine of the "book of deeds" (kitab), wherein actions are preserved by divine scribes (Q 82:10–12), yet Shia tradition adds that the Imams themselves bear witness to these records, reflecting their role as intermediaries of truth. Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the ethical imperative of *muhasabah al-nafs* (self-accountability), a practice emphasized in Shia spirituality to align one’s life with the scales of divine justice. Thus, the verse transcends mere retribution, inviting a profound introspection into the soul’s preparation for its ultimate encounter with the Divine.
14.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Takwir’s declaration that “a soul will know what it has brought” resonates as a profound call to existential accountability. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi frames this verse as an awakening to the “unavoidable intimacy between action and consequence,” emphasizing that humanity’s deeds—both material and spiritual—are indelibly imprinted on the soul. Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to neuroethical research, noting how neuroscience reveals the brain’s capacity to “store” moral choices, creating neural pathways that reflect our lifelong habits—a tangible echo of the Quranic idea that souls “carry” their deeds.

Socially, the verse speaks to today’s crises of environmental neglect and systemic inequality. Grand Ayatollah Hussein Ismail al-Sadr has linked the “what it has brought” clause to ecological responsibility, arguing that humanity’s exploitation of nature will manifest as a spiritual burden. This aligns with Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’* interfaith dialogue, where ecological harm is framed as a moral failing transcending religious boundaries. Philosophically, scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim contextualize the verse within postmodern individualism, urging Muslims to resist a culture of blame-shifting and reclaim agency in an age of social media-driven detachment.

The verse’s multicultural relevance emerges in its universal theme: every soul’s ultimate self-confrontation. Buddhist concepts of karma and Christian notions of divine judgment find common ground here, fostering interfaith solidarity in addressing shared challenges like climate anxiety and digital dehumanization.
14.layer4:
On the Day of Reckoning described in Surah At-Takwir, every soul will confront the eternal consequences of its earthly choices. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) unveils the profound depth of "what it has brought" in this verse, teaching: "It refers to the recognition (ma'rifah) of the Imam of one’s time – whoever dies without this recognition dies the death of ignorance." This transforms the verse from a general accounting of deeds into a spiritual awakening about humanity’s ultimate purpose: conscious submission to Divine Guidance through the Muhammadan Light embodied in the Ahlul Bayt.  

The Sixth Imam further explains that "bringing forth" refers to one’s state of heart when meeting Allah – either adorned with the jewels of wilayah (divine guardianship through love of the Imams) or burdened by rejection of this sacred covenant. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) warned in her famous sermon: "You are accountable for the trusts... the greatest trust is the wilayah of Ali." Every action becomes a mirror reflecting either alignment with or distance from the Imams’ purified path.  

Practical wisdom emerges: daily self-audit (muhasabah) as taught by Imam Ali (peace be upon him) – "Hold yourself accountable before you’re held accountable." Each night, believers should ask: Did my thoughts, words, and deeds today bring me closer to the Imams’ standard of justice, compassion, and truth? Did I defend the oppressed as Hussain did? Did I spread knowledge as patiently as Sajjad?  

This verse ultimately reveals that Judgment Day begins today – every moment is an opportunity to "bring forth" either the light of Imamah or the darkness of neglect. Our souls are eternal vessels; what we fill them with through love for the Fourteen Luminaries determines their final radiance.

14.layer5:
In examining *Surah At-Takwir* 81:14, both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur that the verse refers to the Day of Judgment, when every soul will confront the full reality of its deeds. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) both emphasize the universal accountability implied in “what it has brought,” interpreting this as deeds recorded in one’s spiritual “record” (*kitab*). Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tabatabai (Shia) similarly stress the soul’s awakening to its moral choices, underscoring shared eschatological principles of divine justice and self-awareness before God.

A key divergence arises in contextualizing “what it has brought.” Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir frame this as individual responsibility without mediation, aligning with Sunni emphasis on direct divine reckoning. In contrast, Shia sources such as Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* and Al-Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* often link the verse to the soul’s preparedness through adherence to divinely guided authorities (the Imams), reflecting the Shia theological principle of *walayah* (allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt). This difference stems from distinct understandings of spiritual intercession: Sunni scholars like Al-Razi prioritize God’s unmediated judgment, while Shia traditions integrate the Imams’ role as guides to righteous action.

Historically, these interpretations reflect early theological debates on authority and salvation. Sunni exegesis developed alongside hadith-centric approaches, whereas Shia tafsir intertwined Quranic meaning with the teachings of the Imams. Despite these differences, both traditions agree the verse inspires ethical vigilance, urging believers to cultivate piety (*taqwa*) through daily actions. Such interpretations reinforce shared Islamic values while illustrating how doctrinal priorities shape textual engagement.

14.summary: According to Tafsir al-Mizan, this verse emphasizes the ontological transformation in human perception on that Day: the soul’s limited earthly awareness is replaced by a divinely illuminated consciousness (*ma’rifah haqqah*), enabling it to comprehend the true weight of its choices. In Surah At-Takwir, verse 14 – *عَلِمَتْ نَفْسٌۭ مَّآ أَحْضَرَتْ* – Allah describes a profound moment on the Day of Judgment when every soul will fully comprehend the consequences of its earthly life. The phrase *"ma ahdarat"* (what it has brought) refers to the deeds, intentions, and spiritual state each individual carries into the hereafter. Shia tafsir, as emphasized by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, explains that this "bringing forth" isn’t limited to physical actions but includes the hidden realities of one’s soul – the sincerity of worship, moral choices, and even unspoken truths that define one’s relationship with Allah. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) unveils the profound depth of "what it has brought" in this verse, teaching: "It refers to the recognition (ma'rifah) of the Imam of one’s time – whoever dies without this recognition dies the death of ignorance. As Imam Ali (AS) taught, "The Day of Judgment is already present in your awareness of it" – a truth that transforms how we live today.

15.layer1:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 15, Allah begins a profound oath with the words *"Fa la uqsimu bil-khunnas"* – "So I swear by the retreating stars" – drawing attention to celestial phenomena as signs of divine power. The term *khunnas* (الخنس) refers to stars or planets that appear to retreat or vanish, either due to their orbital movements (like Venus and Mercury, which show retrograde motion) or their disappearance at dawn. Classical Shia tafsir by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* explains that Allah uses these cosmic realities – observable yet mysterious – to affirm the truth of the coming Resurrection described in the surrounding verses. The Meccan context of this revelation highlights its purpose: challenging the pre-Islamic Arabs’ skepticism about the afterlife by appealing to their awe of the night sky they revered.

The oath underscores a key Qur’anic theme: the universe operates by Allah’s flawless design, and its intricate order mirrors the certainty of divine justice. For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on both the physical cosmos and the "retreating" distractions of worldly life. Just as stars withdraw from sight yet remain governed by divine laws, believers are reminded to look beyond transient material pursuits and focus on enduring spiritual truths. The imagery also resonates with modern scientific discoveries about planetary motion and cosmic cycles, reinforcing faith in a Creator whose signs permeate all layers of existence. By contemplating such verses, Muslims cultivate *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) and humility, recognizing that the same Power orchestrating celestial movements governs human destiny – a timeless lesson in balancing worldly engagement with eternal perspective.
15.layer2:
In Surah al-Takwir’s 15th verse, *“So I swear by the retreating stars”*, classical Shia exegetes emphasize both the cosmological and metaphysical dimensions of the oath. The term *al-khunnas* (الخُنَّسِ)—translated as “retreating” or “concealing” stars—is interpreted through literal and allegorical lenses. Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* notes that *khunnas* refers to celestial bodies that “retreat” from visibility, such as stars fading at dawn or planets with retrograde motion, symbolizing the transient nature of creation and Allah’s absolute sovereignty over cosmic order. This oath, he argues, underscores the inevitability of the Day of Judgment described in preceding verses, anchoring divine truth in observable cosmic phenomena (Tafsir al-Mizan, 20:186).  

Sheikh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* expands this, noting that stars—as guides in darkness—are metaphors for the Ahl al-Bayt, who illuminate spiritual and intellectual darkness. The “retreating” motion alludes to their temporal occultation or subtle presence amid societal deviation, a theme resonant with Shia theology’s emphasis on the Imam’s guiding role even when hidden. This aligns with narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who described the Imams as “stars of guidance” whose light persists despite earthly obscurity (Bihar al-Anwar, 24:191).  

Theologically, the verse reinforces the Shia principle of *tawhid al-af’al* (unity of divine acts), where celestial movements reflect Allah’s will, inseparable from His eternal knowledge. The oath also connects to the doctrine of *imamah*, wherein cosmic order and divine guidance are intertwined; just as stars govern physical navigation, the Imams govern spiritual direction. Jurisprudentially, this underscores the necessity of adhering to the *Ma’sumin* (infallibles) as interpreters of divine law, whose authority, like the stars, remains constant despite human neglect.  

Thus, the verse bridges cosmology and creed, affirming both Allah’s mastery over creation and the unbroken chain of guidance through the Ahl al-Bayt—a duality central to Shia thought.
15.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Takwir’s enigmatic reference to “retreating stars” (al-khunnas) has sparked rich dialogue between classical cosmology and modern science. Scholars like Ayatollah Jawadi Amuli and Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali highlight how the verse’s oath—rooted in celestial motion—invites reflection on cosmic harmony as a sign of divine wisdom. Classical commentaries linked “khunnas” to stars’ cyclical visibility or gravitational dynamics, but modern thinkers extend this to phenomena like black holes, whose light-bending properties and “retreating” event horizons align metaphorically with the Quranic imagery. This bridges *tawhid* (divine unity) with astrophysical laws, framing creation as an integrated system demanding both scientific inquiry and spiritual humility.

Socially, the verse’s cosmic metaphor resonates with contemporary struggles against ecological exploitation and societal inequity. Ayatollah Khamenei’s emphasis on environmental stewardship as a Quranic imperative finds echoes here: just as stars retreat from human hubris, Earth’s resources withdraw under unsustainable practices. Philosophically, the “retreating” motif challenges materialist worldviews, urging recognition of unseen forces—both spiritual (ghayb) and quantum—that shape existence. 

Interfaith parallels emerge in dialogues with astrophysicists like Dr. Bruno Guiderdoni, a Muslim astronomer, who notes how Islamic cosmology’s emphasis on cosmic submission (taslim) mirrors Indigenous and Buddhist reverence for natural order. In multicultural contexts, this verse becomes a call to transcend anthropocentrism, fostering global solidarity against climate collapse and AI-driven alienation. By framing celestial retreat as both a scientific marvel and ethical metaphor, Shia scholarship revitalizes this verse as a roadmap for navigating modernity’s dislocations—urging balance between technological progress, ecological justice, and the humility inherent in Quranic cosmology.
15.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah At-Takwir, Allah swears by "the retreating stars" – a profound oath that Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains through the lens of divine guardianship. The Sixth Imam taught that these celestial bodies symbolize the Ahlul Bayt themselves, whose spiritual light appears withdrawn from those blinded by worldly attachments, yet radiates eternally for the sincere seeker. He states in Bihar al-Anwar: *"We are the stars of guidance – when we withdraw from a people, they fall into misguidance as stars fall from heaven."*  

This imagery reflects the Shia understanding of Wilayah – the belief that the Fourteen Infallibles form the cosmic axis through which divine light reaches creation. Just as stars retreat in daylight yet remain present, the Imams' physical absence (like the occultation of Imam Mahdi) doesn't diminish their spiritual luminosity. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) embodied this reality when she described her father Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) as *"the brilliant star for those who navigate darkness"* (Bihar al-Anwar 43/54), establishing the principle that divine guidance continues through the purified progeny.  

Practically, this verse calls believers to cultivate "night vision" of the heart – the ability to perceive hidden guidance through spiritual discipline. Daily dhikr of the Ahlul Bayt's names, contemplation of their sufferings, and adherence to their ethical teachings become lenses to discern their retreating light. Imam Ali (pbuh) advises in Nahj al-Balagha: *"Purify your hearts like polished mirrors, and the stars of truth will never hide from you."*  

Thus, the "retreating stars" ultimately symbolize the dynamic relationship between human effort and divine grace – the more we withdraw from egoistic desires, the more the celestial light of the Muhammadan Reality (Haqiqah Muhammadiyyah) approaches to guide our souls home.

حلف نے ایک کلیدی قرآنی موضوع کی نشاندہی کی ہے: کائنات اللہ کے بے عیب ڈیزائن کے ذریعہ چلتی ہے ، اور اس کا پیچیدہ حکم الہی انصاف کی یقین کو آئینہ دار کرتا ہے۔ عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت جسمانی برہمانڈ اور دنیاوی زندگی کے "پیچھے ہٹتے" خلفشار دونوں پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ جس طرح ستارے نظروں سے دستبردار ہوجاتے ہیں لیکن الہی قوانین کے ذریعہ ابھی تک حکمرانی کی جاتی ہے ، اسی طرح مومنین کو عارضی مادی تعاقب سے بالاتر نظر آنے اور روحانی سچائیوں کو برداشت کرنے پر توجہ دینے کی یاد دلاتی ہے۔ منظر کشی سیاروں کی تحریک اور کائناتی چکروں کے بارے میں جدید سائنسی دریافتوں سے بھی گونجتی ہے ، جس سے ایک ایسے تخلیق کار میں اعتماد کو تقویت ملتی ہے جس کی علامتیں وجود کی تمام پرتوں کو پامال کرتی ہیں۔ اس طرح کی آیات پر غور کرنے سے ، مسلمان * توکوکول * (اللہ پر اعتماد) اور عاجزی کاشت کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ تسلیم کرتے ہیں کہ آسمانی تحریکوں کو ایک ہی طاقت کا ارتکاب کرنے سے انسانی تقدیر پر حکمرانی ہوتی ہے۔

سورہ الکوویر کی 15 ویں آیت میں ، *"لہذا میں پیچھے ہٹتے ہوئے ستاروں کی قسم کھاتا ہوں" *، کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ حلف کے کائناتی اور استعاریاتی دونوں جہتوں پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ اصطلاح * الخوناس * (القانقیوسس)-جس کا ترجمہ "پیچھے ہٹنا" یا "چھپانے" کے ستاروں کے طور پر کیا گیا ہے ، جس کی ترجمانی لفظی اور نظریاتی عینک کے ذریعہ کی جاتی ہے۔ * المزان * میں الامہ تبتابائی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ * خوناس * سے مراد وہ آسمانی جسموں سے مراد ہے جو مرئیت سے "پسپائی" کرتے ہیں ، جیسے ستارے ڈان یا سیاروں میں پیچھے ہٹتے ہوئے موشن کے ساتھ ہوتے ہیں ، جو تخلیق کی عارضی نوعیت اور اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری کی علامت ہیں۔ اس کا استدلال ہے ، اس کا استدلال ہے ، سابقہ آیات میں بیان کردہ یومیہ فیصلے کی ناگزیر ہونے کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جو مشاہدہ کائناتی مظاہر میں الہی سچائی کو لنگر انداز کرتا ہے (طافسیر المزن ، 20: 186)۔  

شیخ تبریسی کے * مجس البیان * نے اس کو وسعت دی ، یہ نوٹ کرتے ہوئے کہ ستارے-اندھیرے میں رہنمائی کے طور پر ، احل ال بیت کے استعارے ہیں ، جو روحانی اور فکری تاریکی کو روشن کرتے ہیں۔ معاشرتی انحراف کے درمیان "پیچھے ہٹنا" تحریک ان کے عارضی جادو یا لطیف موجودگی کا اشارہ کرتی ہے ، جو ایک تھیم تھا جس میں شیعہ الہیات کی طرف سے امام کے رہنمائی کردار پر زور دیا جاتا ہے یہاں تک کہ پوشیدہ۔ اس سے امام جعفر السادق کی بیانات کے مطابق ہے ، جس نے اماموں کو "رہنمائی کے ستارے" کے طور پر بیان کیا جس کی روشنی دنیاوی مبہم ہونے کے باوجود برقرار ہے (بہار الانور ، 24: 191)۔  

مذہبی طور پر ، آیت * توحید الافال * (الہی عمل کا اتحاد) کے شیعہ اصول کو تقویت بخشتی ہے ، جہاں آسمانی تحریکیں اللہ کی مرضی کی عکاسی کرتی ہیں ، جو اس کے ابدی علم سے الگ نہیں ہوتی ہیں۔ حلف *امامہ *کے نظریے سے بھی جڑتا ہے ، جس میں کائناتی ترتیب اور خدائی رہنمائی ایک دوسرے سے جڑی ہوئی ہے۔ جس طرح ستارے جسمانی نیویگیشن پر حکمرانی کرتے ہیں ، اسی طرح امام روحانی سمت پر حکومت کرتے ہیں۔ فقہی طور پر ، اس سے الہی قانون کے ترجمان کی حیثیت سے * ماوسمین * (انفالیبلز) پر عمل پیرا ہونے کی ضرورت کی نشاندہی ہوتی ہے ، جس کا اختیار ، ستاروں کی طرح ، انسانی نظرانداز کے باوجود مستقل رہتا ہے۔  

اس طرح ، آیت کائناتولوجی اور مسلک کو پل کرتی ہے ، جس میں اللہ کی تخلیق اور اے ایچ ایل ال بیت کے ذریعہ رہنمائی کی اٹوٹ زنجیر دونوں کی تصدیق ہوتی ہے۔

عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ اتاکویر کے "پیچھے ہٹانے والے ستاروں" (الخوناس) کے بارے میں خفیہ حوالہ نے کلاسیکی کائناتولوجی اور جدید سائنس کے مابین بھرپور مکالمے کو جنم دیا ہے۔ آیت اللہ جوادی امولی اور ڈاکٹر محمد علی شمالی جیسے اسکالرز اس بات پر روشنی ڈالتے ہیں کہ آسمانی تحریک میں اس آیت کی قسم کی قسم کس طرح ہے۔ کلاسیکی تبصرے نے "کھوناز" کو ستاروں کی چکرمک مرئیت یا کشش ثقل کی حرکیات سے منسلک کیا ، لیکن جدید مفکرین اس کو بلیک ہولز جیسے مظاہر تک بڑھا دیتے ہیں ، جن کی ہلکی موڑنے والی خصوصیات اور "پیچھے ہٹنا" واقعہ افق افق قرآنی امیجری کے ساتھ استعاراتی طور پر سیدھ میں رکھتے ہیں۔ اس پلوں کو * تاؤہد * (الہی اتحاد) فلکیاتی طبی قوانین کے ساتھ ، تخلیق کو ایک مربوط نظام کے طور پر تشکیل دیتے ہیں جو سائنسی تفتیش اور روحانی عاجزی دونوں کا مطالبہ کرتے ہیں۔

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت کا کائناتی استعارہ ماحولیاتی استحصال اور معاشرتی عدم مساوات کے خلاف عصری جدوجہد کے ساتھ گونجتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ خمینیئ نے ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری پر زور دیا ہے کیونکہ قرآنی لازمی لازمی طور پر یہاں بازگشت پائے جاتے ہیں: جس طرح ستارے انسانی حبس سے پیچھے ہٹتے ہیں ، اسی طرح زمین کے وسائل غیر مستحکم طریقوں سے دستبردار ہوجاتے ہیں۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، "پیچھے ہٹنا" شکل مادیت پسند دنیا کے نظارے کو چیلنج کرتی ہے ، اور نہ ہی دیکھے ہوئے قوتوں - دونوں روحانی (غئی بی) اور کوانٹم کو تسلیم کرنے پر زور دیتے ہیں جو وجود کی شکل دیتے ہیں۔ 

ایک مسلمان ماہر فلکیات ، ڈاکٹر برونو گائیڈڈونی جیسے ماہر فلکیات کے ماہرین کے ساتھ بات چیت میں بین المذاہب متوازی سامنے آتے ہیں ، جو نوٹ کرتے ہیں کہ کس طرح اسلامی کائناتولوجی کا کائناتی جمع کرانے (تاسلم) پر دیسی اور بدھ مت کے عقیدت کے لئے آئینہ دار ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، یہ آیت آب و ہوا کے خاتمے اور اے آئی سے چلنے والی بیگانگی کے خلاف عالمی یکجہتی کو فروغ دینے کے لئے انتھروپوسنٹرزم کو عبور کرنے کی کال بن جاتی ہے۔ سائنسی تعطل اور اخلاقی استعارے دونوں کی حیثیت سے آسمانی اعتکاف کا آغاز کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اسکالرشپ اس آیت کو جدیدیت کے سندچیوتیوں کو نیویگیٹ کرنے کے لئے روڈ میپ کے طور پر زندہ کرتا ہے۔

سورہ اتاکویر کی برائٹ آیت میں ، اللہ "پسپائی ستاروں" کی قسم کھاتا ہے-ایک گہرا حلف کہ امام جعفر السادق (اس پر امن ہے) الہی سرپرستی کے عینک کے ذریعہ وضاحت کرتا ہے۔ چھٹے امام نے سکھایا کہ یہ آسمانی جسم خود اہل بیت کی علامت ہیں ، جن کی روحانی روشنی دنیاوی منسلکات سے اندھے ہونے والوں سے واپس لی جاتی ہے ، پھر بھی مخلص سالک کے لئے ہمیشہ کے لئے پھیل جاتی ہے۔ وہ بہار الانور میں کہتے ہیں: *"ہم رہنمائی کے ستارے ہیں-جب ہم کسی لوگوں سے دستبردار ہوجاتے ہیں تو ، ستارے جنت سے گرتے ہی وہ گمراہی میں پڑ جاتے ہیں۔" *  

یہ منظر کشی ولیہ کے بارے میں شیعہ کی تفہیم کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ جس طرح ستارے دن کی روشنی میں پیچھے ہٹتے ہیں ، ابھی تک موجود ہیں ، اسی طرح اماموں کی جسمانی عدم موجودگی (جیسے امام مہدی کے جادو) ان کی روحانی روشنی کو کم نہیں کرتی ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن) اس حقیقت کو اس وقت مجسم بناتے ہیں جب انہوں نے اپنے والد نبی محمد (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) کو * "اندھیرے پر جانے والوں کے لئے ایک شاندار اسٹار" کے طور پر بیان کیا تھا " * (بہار الانور 43/54) ، اس اصول کو قائم کرتے ہوئے کہ الہی ہدایت نامہ تقویت کے ذریعہ جاری ہے۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو دل کی "نائٹ وژن" کاشت کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ احلول بیت کے ناموں کے روزانہ دھکر ، ان کے دکھوں پر غور و فکر ، اور ان کی اخلاقی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہونا ان کی پسپائی کی روشنی کو سمجھنے کے ل len عینک بن جاتا ہے۔ امام علی (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) ناہج البالاگھا میں مشورہ دیتے ہیں: "اپنے دلوں کو پالش آئینے کی طرح پاک کریں ، اور سچائی کے ستارے کبھی بھی آپ سے پوشیدہ نہیں ہوں گے۔" *  

اس طرح ، "پیچھے ہٹتے ہوئے ستارے" بالآخر انسانی کوششوں اور خدائی فضل کے مابین متحرک تعلقات کی علامت ہیں - ہم اناسٹک خواہشات سے جتنا زیادہ دستبردار ہوجاتے ہیں ، اتنا ہی محمدن حقیقت کی آسمانی روشنی (حققہ محمدیہ) ہماری روحوں کے گھر کی رہنمائی کے لئے پہنچتی ہے۔
15.layer5:
The interpretation of *falā uqsimu bi-l-khunnas* (“I swear by the retreating stars”) reveals both shared cosmological principles and distinct theological emphases across Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions. Classical scholars from both schools broadly concur that *al-khunnas* refers to celestial bodies—particularly planets or stars—that “retreat” (*khanasa*) in their orbits or luminosity, as noted by Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia). This reflects a shared Qur’anic motif of cosmic phenomena as signs (*āyāt*) of divine power, a theme emphasized in Al-Qurtubi’s *Ahkam* and Al-Tabarsi’s *Majma al-Bayan*.  

Divergences emerge in symbolic interpretations. Sunni commentators like Al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) and Ibn Kathir prioritize literal astronomical explanations, linking *khunnas* to observable planetary motions. Al-Razi argues the oath underscores Allah’s creative mastery over celestial order, a perspective echoed in Al-Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan*. In contrast, Shia exegetes such as Al-Qummi and Al-Tabarsi (via *Majma al-Bayan*) incorporate esoteric (*bāṭinī*) dimensions, suggesting *khunnas* alludes to spiritual realities. Al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) posits the verse metaphorically references the “retreat” of worldly distractions, enabling focus on divine truth—a view aligning with Shia emphasis on inner spiritual purification under the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt.  

Theological foundations for these differences stem from distinct hermeneutical approaches. Sunni tafsir often prioritizes transmitted (*naqli*) knowledge and apparent (*ẓāhir*) meanings, whereas Shia traditions—rooted in the Imams’ teachings—integrate symbolic interpretations reflecting the belief in divinely inspired hermeneutics. Historically, Shia esotericism developed alongside theological doctrines of Imamah, while Sunni emphasis on accessible textual meanings reflects early efforts to standardize exegesis across diverse communities.  

While these interpretations do not directly affect ritual practice, they shape cosmological worldviews: Sunni readings reinforce Allah’s sovereignty through natural phenomena, while Shia perspectives often intertwine cosmic signs with spiritual guidance. Both traditions, however, unite in affirming the verse’s ultimate purpose: to awaken contemplation of divine majesty.

* فال ā ی کیویمو دو-ایل-خوناس * ("میں پیچھے ہٹتے ہوئے ستاروں کی قسم کھاتا ہوں") کی ترجمانی شیعہ اور سنی کی معتبر روایات میں مشترکہ کائناتی اصولوں اور الگ الگ مذہبی زوروں کو ظاہر کرتی ہے۔ دونوں اسکولوں سے تعلق رکھنے والے کلاسیکی اسکالرز بڑے پیمانے پر اس بات پر متفق ہیں کہ*الخوناس*سے مراد آسمانی جسموں-خاص طور پر سیارے یا ستارے ہیں-جو "اعتکاف" (*خاناسا*) اپنے مدار میں یا روشنی میں ہیں ، جیسا کہ العباری (سنی) اور الدمبیسی (شیا) نے نوٹ کیا ہے۔ اس سے الہی طاقت کے اشارے (*āyāt*) کے طور پر کائناتی مظاہر کے مشترکہ قرآنی شکل کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے ، جس میں القوروبی کے*احکام*اور الاتارسی کے*مجمہ البیان*میں زور دیا گیا تھا۔  

علامتی تشریحات میں تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ سنی مفسرین جیسے العزی (*مافاتیہ الغیب*) اور ابن کتھیر لفظی فلکیاتی وضاحتوں کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، اور*کھوناس*کو مشاہدہ کرنے والے سیاروں کی حرکات سے جوڑتے ہیں۔ الراجی نے استدلال کیا ہے کہ حلف برداری نے اللہ کی تخلیقی مہارت کو آسمانی ترتیب پر زور دیا ہے ، یہ ایک نقطہ نظر الضری کے *جامی البیان *میں گونجتا ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ القومی اور التابرسسی (*ماجما البیان*کے توسط سے) جیسے باطنی (*بآنی*) طول و عرض کو شامل کرتے ہیں ، جس میں یہ تجویز کیا گیا ہے کہ*کھوناناس*روحانی حقائق کا اشارہ کرتے ہیں۔ الاتعباتابائی (*المزان*) نے آیت کو استعاراتی طور پر دنیاوی خلفشار کی "اعتکاف" کا حوالہ دیا ہے ، جس سے خدائی سچائی پر توجہ مرکوز کی جاسکتی ہے۔ یہ ایک نظریہ ہے جس کا نظارہ شیعہ البیٹ کی رہنمائی کے تحت اندرونی روحانی تزکیہ پر زور دینے کے ساتھ ہے۔  

ان اختلافات کے لئے مذہبی بنیادیں الگ الگ ہرمینیٹیکل نقطہ نظر سے پیدا ہوتی ہیں۔ سنی طافسیر اکثر منتقل ہونے والی (*نقلی*) علم اور ظاہر (*ẓāhir*) کے معنی کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ روایات - جو اماموں کی تعلیمات میں جڑی ہوئی ہیں - انضمام علامتی تشریحات جو خدائی طور پر متاثرہ ہرمینیٹکس میں عقیدے کی عکاسی کرتی ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، شیعہ باطنی مذہب کے مذہبی عقائد کے ساتھ ساتھ تیار ہوا ہے ، جبکہ قابل رسائی متنی معانی پر سنی پر زور دینے سے متنوع برادریوں میں استثنیٰ کو معیاری بنانے کی ابتدائی کوششوں کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے۔  

اگرچہ یہ تشریحات براہ راست رسمی عمل کو متاثر نہیں کرتی ہیں ، لیکن وہ کائناتی عالمی نظریات کی تشکیل کرتے ہیں: سنی ریڈنگس قدرتی مظاہر کے ذریعہ اللہ کی خودمختاری کو تقویت بخشتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ کے نقطہ نظر اکثر روحانی رہنمائی کے ساتھ کائناتی علامتوں کو جوڑتے ہیں۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے حتمی مقصد کی تصدیق میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں: الہی عظمت کے غور و فکر کو بیدار کرنا۔
15.summary: Tafsir al-Mizan offers profound insights, with Tabatabai noting that *khunnas* refers to celestial bodies that “retreat” from visibility, such as stars fading at dawn or planets with retrograde motion, symbolizing the transient nature of creation and Allah’s absolute sovereignty over cosmic order. In Surah At-Takwir, verse 15, Allah begins a profound oath with the words *"Fa la uqsimu bil-khunnas"* – "So I swear by the retreating stars" – drawing attention to celestial phenomena as signs of divine power. The term *khunnas* (الخنس) refers to stars or planets that appear to retreat or vanish, either due to their orbital movements (like Venus and Mercury, which show retrograde motion) or their disappearance at dawn. Classical Shia tafsir by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* explains that Allah uses these cosmic realities – observable yet mysterious – to affirm the truth of the coming Resurrection described in the surrounding verses. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains through the lens of divine guardianship. this verse invites reflection on both the physical cosmos and the "retreating" distractions of worldly life.

16.layer1:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 16, Allah swears by "al-jawari al-kunnas" – a phrase rich in cosmic imagery central to the Quran’s depiction of divine power. Classical Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Shaykh Tabarsi in *Majma al-Bayan* explain this verse as an oath by celestial bodies that move in precise orbits (jawari, from *j-w-r*, "to flow" or "run") and vanish from sight (kunnas, from *k-n-s*, "to sweep away" or "retreat"). These terms are widely interpreted as references to stars or planets that appear to "disappear" during daylight or due to their orbital paths, reflecting the Quran’s recurring theme of cosmic order as proof of Allah’s wisdom.  

Revealed in Mecca during intense opposition to the Prophet (PBUH), this verse – like much of Surah At-Takwir – uses awe-inspiring natural phenomena to affirm the inevitability of the Day of Judgment. The disbelievers dismissed resurrection as impossible, but Allah draws attention to the flawless, purposeful motion of heavenly bodies as evidence of His ability to recreate existence. For early Muslims, this reinforced the link between observing nature and recognizing divine truth – a principle echoed in the teachings of Imam Ali (AS), who urged people to "look at the sky" to grasp Allah’s greatness.  

Today, this verse invites Muslims to reflect on the transient yet perfectly balanced universe as a mirror of spiritual truths. The "running" stars remind us that everything in creation has a purpose and a divinely ordained path – a lesson in surrendering to Allah’s plan (tawakkul). The "disappearing" aspect of kunnas underscores the temporary nature of worldly life, urging believers to focus on lasting spiritual goals. In an age of scientific discovery, this verse also encourages the integration of faith and reason: studying astronomy or physics becomes an act of worship when it deepens our awe for the Creator’s design. By contemplating these celestial signs, we renew our humility and gratitude, aligning our lives with the cosmic harmony ordained by Allah.
16.layer2:
In Surah al-Takwir 81:16, Allah swears by "al-jawari al-kunnas" – "those that run [their courses] and disappear" – a phrase receiving nuanced interpretation in classical Shia exegesis. Both Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* emphasize this as referring to celestial bodies, particularly stars exhibiting dual characteristics: swift orbital motion (jawari) and periodic occultation (kunnas). Tabrisi notes this describes planets like Mercury and Venus, whose retrograde movements and temporary disappearances at dawn/dusk horizons exemplify the verse's imagery (Majma al-Bayan 10/679). Tabatabai expands this cosmologically, observing that the "running" reflects the divinely ordained precision of celestial mechanics, while "disappearing" underscores creation's transient nature compared to Allah's eternal sovereignty (Al-Mizan 20/197).

Theological implications emerge through the Shia lens of cosmic 'amr (divine command). The stars' submission to celestial order mirrors humanity's obligation to follow divine guidance through the Prophet and Ahl al-Bayt. As celestial bodies vanish yet remain governed by Allah's laws, so too must earthly existence be understood through the lens of ghayba (occultation) – the hidden yet active governance of the Twelfth Imam. This connects to Shia eschatology, where cosmic phenomena in Surah al-Takwir signal both physical and metaphysical transformations preceding the Hour.

Jurisprudentially, the oath underscores Islam's integration of natural observation with spiritual truth – a principle foundational to Shia ilm al-hadith, where rational inquiry complements transmitted knowledge. The verse's cosmic imagery ultimately affirms Tawhid, demonstrating creation's total dependence on the Creator, a theme recurrent in sermons of Imam Ali recorded in *Nahj al-Balagha*. Thus, classical Shia commentary synthesizes astronomical precision, theological doctrine, and the ontological reality of divine guidance through the Imamate.
16.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Takwir’s reference to “those that run and disappear” (al-jawari al-kunnas) is often explored through interdisciplinary lenses. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, interprets these celestial bodies as dynamic cosmic phenomena reflecting divine precision—a theme resonating with modern astrophysics. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali note how the verse’s imagery of orbiting and vanishing stars parallels scientific understandings of comets, black holes, or neutron stars, whose gravitational forces “sweep away” light, aligning with the term *kunnas* (to conceal or collect). This bridges the Quran’s 7th-century cosmic language with 21st-century discoveries, emphasizing Islam’s harmony with empirical inquiry.

Philosophically, the verse invites reflection on transient power structures and the fragility of human dominance—a timely metaphor for climate crises and geopolitical instability. The “disappearing” celestial paths mirror humanity’s fleeting control over nature, urging humility and ecological stewardship. Socially, it critiques materialism, paralleling Imam Ali’s teachings on detachment from worldly arrogance (Ghurar al-Hikam).

Interfaith dialogues find common ground here: Buddhist impermanence (anicca), Hindu cyclical time (kalpas), and Indigenous cosmologies all resonate with this Quranic motif. In multicultural contexts, the verse becomes a call for shared ethical responsibility—whether in addressing space debris threatening satellites or advocating for climate justice.

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern believers to see science and spirituality as complementary: cosmic order as both a divine sign and a catalyst for ethical innovation. As Shia theologian Dr. Liyakat Takim notes, such verses inspire “awe-driven activism,” merging tawhid (divine unity) with sustainable progress—a vision vital for navigating today’s global uncertainties.
16.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah At-Takwir, Allah swears by "the stars that move swiftly and vanish" (81:16). The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound spiritual dimensions here. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that these celestial bodies symbolize the divine Guides whose light navigates humanity through life's darkness. He states: *"The 'running stars' are the Imams from the progeny of Muhammad. They traverse the heavens of guidance with divine speed, yet remain hidden from those veiled by worldly attachments."*  

The term "al-kunnas" (those that disappear) alludes to the Imam's station of spiritual concealment – not physical absence, but the reality that their true radiance is perceived only by hearts purified through devotion to Wilayah. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized this truth: *"The Ark of Salvation sails through tempests of ignorance; its passengers are those who hold fast to the Rope of Allah's chosen Ones."*  

Practically, this verse calls believers to align their souls with the Imams' cosmic rhythm. Just as stars withdraw from daylight yet govern the night, the Ahlul Bayt's guidance operates beyond sensory perception. To "disappear" like these stars means to detach from ego-driven existence through:  
1) Constant remembrance (dhikr) of the Imam's presence in creation  
2) Seeking inner vision to perceive their light in times of spiritual obscurity  
3) Emulating their ethical orbit through Quranic adherence and service to creation  

The 12th Imam (may Allah hasten his reappearance) embodies this principle – his occultation mirrors the star's vanishing act, yet his nourishing light sustains faithful hearts. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advised: *"Be like the stars – travelers through darkness, leaving no trace but illumination."* Through love for the Chosen Household, believers become living reflections of these heavenly runners, their souls ascending toward the Divine Encounter.

سورہ اتاکویر میں ، آیت 16 میں ، اللہ نے "الجواری الکناس" کی قسم کھائی ہے-یہ ایک جملہ جو کائناتی منظر کشی سے مالا مال ہے جو قرآن مجید کے الہی طاقت کی عکاسی کا مرکز ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ طافسر اسکالرز جیسے *المزان *میں الامہ تبتابائی اور شیکہ تبارسی *ماجما البیان *میں اس آیت کو آسمانی جسموں کے حلف کے طور پر بیان کرتے ہیں جو عین مطابق مدار میں منتقل ہوتے ہیں (جوواری ، *J-W-r *سے ، "بہاؤ سے" یا "رن") "اعتکاف")۔ ان شرائط کو بڑے پیمانے پر ستاروں یا سیاروں کے حوالہ جات کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے جو دن کی روشنی کے دوران یا ان کے مداری راستوں کی وجہ سے "غائب" ہوتے دکھائی دیتے ہیں ، جو اللہ کی حکمت کے ثبوت کے طور پر قرآن مجید کے کائناتی ترتیب کے بار بار چلنے والے موضوع کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔  

نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کی شدید مخالفت کے دوران مکہ میں انکشاف کیا گیا ہے ، یہ آیت-جیسے سورہ اتاکویر کی زیادہ تر-یومیہ فیصلے کی ناگزیر ہونے کی تصدیق کے لئے حیرت انگیز قدرتی مظاہر کا استعمال کرتی ہے۔ کافروں نے قیامت کو ناممکن کے طور پر مسترد کردیا ، لیکن اللہ اس کے وجود کو دوبارہ بنانے کی صلاحیت کے ثبوت کے طور پر آسمانی جسموں کی بے عیب ، بامقصد حرکت کی طرف راغب کرتا ہے۔ ابتدائی مسلمانوں کے ل this ، اس سے فطرت کا مشاہدہ کرنے اور خدائی سچائی کو پہچاننے کے مابین روابط کو تقویت ملی - یہ اصول امام علی (ع) کی تعلیمات میں گونج اٹھا ، جس نے لوگوں کو اللہ کی عظمت کو سمجھنے کے لئے "آسمان کو دیکھنے" پر زور دیا۔  

آج ، یہ آیت مسلمانوں کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ روحانی سچائیوں کے آئینے کے طور پر عارضی لیکن بالکل متوازن کائنات پر غور کریں۔ "رننگ" ستارے ہمیں یاد دلاتے ہیں کہ تخلیق میں ہر چیز کا ایک مقصد اور ایک الہی مقرر کردہ راستہ ہے - اللہ کے منصوبے (توواکول) کے حوالے کرنے کا سبق۔ کناس کے "غائب" پہلو سے دنیاوی زندگی کی عارضی نوعیت کی نشاندہی ہوتی ہے ، اور مومنین پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ وہ دیرپا روحانی اہداف پر توجہ دیں۔ سائنسی دریافت کے دور میں ، یہ آیت عقیدے اور استدلال کے انضمام کی بھی حوصلہ افزائی کرتی ہے: فلکیات یا طبیعیات کا مطالعہ ایک عبادت گاہ بن جاتا ہے جب یہ تخلیق کار کے ڈیزائن کے لئے ہمارے خوف کو گہرا کرتا ہے۔ ان آسمانی علامتوں پر غور کرکے ، ہم اپنی عاجزی اور شکرگزار کی تجدید کرتے ہیں ، اور اپنی زندگی کو اللہ کے ذریعہ طے شدہ کائناتی ہم آہنگی کے ساتھ جوڑتے ہیں۔

سورہ الکوئیر 81:16 میں ، اللہ نے "الجواری الکناس" کی قسم کھائی ہے-"وہ جو [اپنے کورسز] چلاتے ہیں اور غائب ہوجاتے ہیں"-کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ میں متناسب تشریح حاصل کرنے والا ایک جملہ۔ * ماجما البیان * میں شیخ تبریسی اور * المزان * میں علامہ تباتابائی دونوں ہی اس پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ وہ آسمانی جسموں کا حوالہ دیتے ہیں ، خاص طور پر ستارے جو دوہری خصوصیات کی نمائش کرتے ہیں: سوئفٹ مداری تحریک (جوااری) اور متواتر جادو (کونس)۔ تبریسی نوٹ کرتے ہیں کہ اس میں پارا اور وینس جیسے سیاروں کی وضاحت کی گئی ہے ، جن کی ڈان/شام کے افق کے وقت پیچھے ہٹ جانے والی حرکتیں اور عارضی گمشدگی آیت کی منظر کشی کی مثال دیتے ہیں (ماجما البیان 10/679)۔ تبتابائی نے اس کائناتی طور پر اس میں توسیع کی ، یہ مشاہدہ کیا گیا ہے کہ "چلانے" سے آسمانی میکانکس کی خدائی طور پر طے شدہ صحت سے متعلق عکاسی ہوتی ہے ، جبکہ اللہ کی ابدی خودمختاری (المزان 20/197) کے مقابلے میں تخلیق کی عارضی نوعیت کی "غائب" ہوتی ہے۔

مذہبی مضمرات کائناتی AMR (الہی کمانڈ) کے شیعہ عینک کے ذریعے ابھرتے ہیں۔ ستاروں کی جانب سے آسمانی آرڈر کے لئے پیش کرنا انسانیت کی ذمہ داری کو آئینہ دار کرتا ہے کہ وہ نبی اور اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کے ذریعہ خدائی رہنمائی پر عمل کریں۔ چونکہ آسمانی لاشیں ختم ہوجاتی ہیں لیکن ابھی تک اللہ کے قوانین کے مطابق رہتی ہیں ، اسی لئے بھی زمینی وجود کو غئیبہ (جادوئی) کے عینک کے ذریعے سمجھنا چاہئے - بارہویں امام کی پوشیدہ لیکن فعال حکمرانی۔ یہ شیعہ ایسکیٹولوجی سے منسلک ہوتا ہے ، جہاں سورہ الکوئیر میں کائناتی مظاہر اس وقت سے پہلے کی جسمانی اور استعاریاتی تبدیلیوں دونوں کا اشارہ کرتا ہے۔

16.layer5:
In interpreting Surah At-Takwir 81:16, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on identifying *al-jawari al-kunnas* as celestial bodies, though nuances emerge in their cosmological and theological elaborations. Classical authorities like Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) agree the verse references stars or planets that "run" in orbits and "disappear" at dawn or seasonally, reflecting premodern astronomical understanding. Ibn Kathir and Qurtubi emphasize this as proof of Allah’s creative power, aligning with Tabatabai’s view in *Al-Mizan* that such phenomena demonstrate divine order in creation.  

Divergences arise in symbolic interpretations. Sunni scholars like Razi in *Mafatih al-Ghayb* generally limit analysis to the verse’s eschatological context within Surah At-Takwir, interpreting the stars’ vanishing as a prelude to cosmic upheaval during the Hour. In contrast, Shia sources such as Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s tafsir occasionally link the imagery to metaphysical principles, with Tabatabai suggesting *al-kunnas* (those that withdraw) may allude to hidden truths or cyclical spiritual guidance through the Imams. This reflects the Shia emphasis on *batin* (esoteric) meanings undergirded by the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings.  

Theological foundations for these differences stem from distinct hermeneutical priorities: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes *zahir* (apparent meaning) and historical context, while Shia tafsir integrates the Imams’ interpretive authority. Such variations rarely impact ritual practice but inform cosmological perspectives, with Shia thought more readily connecting natural phenomena to Imamah’s metaphysical role. Historically, these interpretive trajectories emerged from early scholarly circles in Medina (Sunni) and Kufa/Qom (Shia), shaped by differing epistemological approaches to Quranic ambiguity. Both traditions ultimately uphold the verse’s core function: inspiring awe at divine mastery over creation.

16.summary: This verse, as interpreted in Al-Mizan, *Majma al-Bayan* and Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* emphasize this as referring to celestial bodies, particularly stars exhibiting dual characteristics: swift orbital motion (jawari) and periodic occultation (kunnas). In Surah At-Takwir, verse 16, Allah swears by "al-jawari al-kunnas" – a phrase rich in cosmic imagery central to the Quran’s depiction of divine power. Classical Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Shaykh Tabarsi in *Majma al-Bayan* explain this verse as an oath by celestial bodies that move in precise orbits (jawari, from *j-w-r*, "to flow" or "run") and vanish from sight (kunnas, from *k-n-s*, "to sweep away" or "retreat"). These terms are widely interpreted as references to stars or planets that appear to "disappear" during daylight or due to their orbital paths, reflecting the Quran’s recurring theme of cosmic order as proof of Allah’s wisdom. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that these celestial bodies symbolize the divine Guides whose light navigates humanity through life's darkness. this verse invites Muslims to reflect on the transient yet perfectly balanced universe as a mirror of spiritual truths.

17.layer1:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 17, Allah swears by "wal-layli idhā as'as" — "the night as it closes in" — drawing attention to the profound symbolism of night’s transition. The term *as'as* derives from the root *‘as’asa*, which carries dual meanings of both advancing and retreating, reflecting the dynamic nature of night as it either begins to envelop the world or withdraws at dawn. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that here it refers to the night’s departure at daybreak, symbolizing the inevitable triumph of light over darkness — a recurring Quranic metaphor for divine truth overcoming falsehood. This verse forms part of a series of oaths in Surah At-Takwir (revealed in Mecca) that underscore the Quran’s authenticity and the certainty of the Day of Judgment, challenging the skepticism of early Quraysh leaders who dismissed resurrection as impossible.

The imagery of night retreating aligns with the Shia understanding of guidance through the Ahlul Bayt, who illuminate spiritual and moral darkness. Just as physical night yields to morning, the verse reassures believers that periods of hardship, doubt, or societal corruption are temporary. For contemporary Muslims, this serves as a call to reflect on life’s transient struggles and to seek solace in prayer and Quranic wisdom during the night’s stillness, as emphasized by Imam Ali’s teachings on night worship. It also inspires active hope: just as dawn follows darkness, collective efforts to uphold justice and truth — rooted in the teachings of the Prophet and his family — will ultimately prevail. The verse thus becomes a timeless reminder to trust in divine rhythm, balance, and the ultimate victory of faith.
17.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates the oath in Surah At-Takwir 81:17 ("And by the night as it closes in") by situating it within the Qur’an’s recurring motif of cosmic phenomena as divine signs (*ayat*). The term *‘as’asa* (عسعس) is linguistically nuanced, denoting both the night’s departure at dawn and its encroachment at dusk. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, reconciles this duality by noting that the verse’s eschatological context favors interpreting *‘as’asa* as the night’s retreat, symbolizing the dissolution of cosmic order preceding the Hour. This aligns with Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s reported emphasis on the Qur’an’s multilayered temporal dimensions, where natural cycles simultaneously reflect primordial creation, ongoing sustenance, and the inevitability of resurrection.

Shia exegetes uniquely link such verses to the ontological role of the Ahl al-Bayt as the "lights of guidance" (*anwar al-huda*) amid existential darkness. The night’s transient obscurity parallels humanity’s periodic alienation from divine truth, remedied by the Imams’ enduring presence as spiritual luminaries. Tabatabai further observes that the verse’s pairing with the subsequent oath ("and by the dawn when it breathes") underscores the Shia theological principle of *badā’* (manifestation of divine will through contingent realities), wherein darkness and light are dynamic, purposeful manifestations of Allah’s wisdom rather than static opposites.

Jurisprudentially, classical scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi drew from such verses to reinforce the obligation of nocturnal worship (*tahajjud*), interpreting the night’s "closing in" as a call to introspection and proximity to the Divine. The verse thus operates on multiple planes: as a testament to Allah’s creative power, a metaphor for the Imamate’s guiding function, and an ethical imperative for spiritual vigilance—a holistic approach characteristic of Shia hermeneutics.
17.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Takwir’s verse 17—“And by the night as it closes in”—is often explored through layered lenses of cosmology, spirituality, and social ethics. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, highlights the rhythmic precision of day-night cycles as a sign of divine order, aligning with modern scientific understandings of Earth’s rotation and circadian rhythms. This interplay between cosmic regularity and human life underscores the Quran’s invitation to reflect on natural phenomena as manifestations of Allah’s wisdom. Scholars like Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari extend this metaphorically, framing the “closing night” as societal ignorance or moral decay, urging communities to seek enlightenment through the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt—a call resonant in an era grappling with misinformation and ethical crises.  

Scientifically, the verse’s imagery connects to environmental discussions. The gradual transition from night to dawn mirrors ecological balance, a theme amplified by contemporary Muslim environmentalists like Dr. Seyyed Hossein Nasr, who link Quranic cosmology to sustainable living. Philosophically, the “closing night” speaks to modern anxieties—existential uncertainty, social fragmentation—inviting individuals to embrace spiritual resilience.  

Globally, the verse’s emphasis on cyclical renewal offers hope amid climate crises or political turmoil, echoing Imam Ali’s teachings on perseverance through hardship. Interfaith parallels emerge in traditions valuing night as sacred time for reflection, such as Jewish *Tikkun Leil* or Christian vigils, fostering shared ethical ground. For Shia communities, this verse becomes a rallying point to address inequality and advocate for justice, embodying the Quran’s dynamic relevance in guiding both personal and collective transformation.
17.layer4:
The oath sworn by the night "as it closes in" (81:17) is illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt as a profound metaphor for spiritual transition and the necessity of divine guidance. Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as) taught that night symbolizes both the veils of ignorance enveloping humanity and the fertile time for soulful devotion: *"The believer has no delight greater than the hours of night standing before his Lord in prayer."* The "closing" darkness represents humanity's drift from truth, while its eventual retreat signifies the dawn of divine light through the Imamah.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) interprets this verse as an allusion to the Ghaybah (occultation) of Imam Mahdi (aj), explaining: *"When night 'closes in' with confusion and trials, know it is the darkness before the rising sun of the Qa'im from us."* Here, the cyclical nature of night becomes a promise – just as physical darkness yields to dawn, spiritual darkness lifts through adherence to the Imams' teachings. Lady Fatimah (sa) emphasized this principle in her famous sermon: *"Night and day are vessels for your deeds – fill them with remembrance of Allah and service to His chosen ones."*

Practically, this verse calls believers to embrace the "night" of worldly distractions as an opportunity for spiritual labor. The Ahlul Bayt taught that true wilayah manifests in using night hours for Quranic reflection, dua Kumayl, and seeking forgiveness. As Imam Ali (as) advised: *"Let your night be longer than your day through prayer, for the night is the believer's treasure-house."* By aligning our inner darkness with the luminous guidance of the Imams, we transform life's "closing nights" into portals toward divine proximity – preparing our souls for both the Mahdi's reappearance and the eternal dawn of resurrection.

17.layer5:
In interpreting Surah At-Takwir 17 (“And by the night as it closes in”), Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core cosmological and theological themes while diverging in nuanced emphases. Both traditions universally regard the verse’s oath as affirming Allah’s sovereignty over cosmic cycles, with night’s transition symbolizing resurrection and divine order. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) both cite the phrase “عَسْعَسَ” (as‘asa) as denoting night’s departure or approach, reflecting classical Arabic’s polysemy. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi similarly align in viewing such oaths as reminders of creation’s perfection, urging spiritual reflection on eschatological realities.

Divergences emerge in hermeneutical priorities. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi emphasize philological analysis and the verse’s literal function as a sign (āyah) of Allah’s power, often linking it to observable natural phenomena. In contrast, Shia works like Al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Tafsir al-Qummi incorporate metaphysical dimensions, interpreting the night’s “closing in” as an allegory for spiritual obscurity preceding divine illumination—a motif tied to the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance. Tabatabai notably connects the imagery to cyclical cosmic renewal, resonating with Shia eschatological expectations of the Mahdi’s advent.

These differences stem from distinct tafsir methodologies: Sunni exegesis often prioritizes textual-literary analysis authenticated by Prophetic tradition (ḥadīth), while Shia approaches integrate Imamite narrations that expand symbolic meanings. Historically, Shia emphasis on the Imams’ hermeneutical authority fostered interpretations linking cosmic phenomena to salvational history, whereas Sunni scholarship’s early institutionalization around linguistic and juridical frameworks reinforced a focus on apparent (ẓāhir) meanings. Both traditions, however, share the verse’s core didactic purpose: to awaken consciousness of divine omnipotence and the inevitability of resurrection, transcending sectarian boundaries in their call to spiritual vigilance.

In Surah At-Takwir, verse 17, Allah swears by "wal-layli idhā as'as" — "the night as it closes in" — drawing attention to the profound symbolism of night’s transition. The term *as'as* derives from the root *‘as’asa*, which carries dual meanings of both advancing and retreating, reflecting the dynamic nature of night as it either begins to envelop the world or withdraws at dawn. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s emphasizes that here it refers to the night’s departure at daybreak, symbolizing the inevitable triumph of light over darkness — a recurring Quranic metaphor for divine truth overcoming falsehood. Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib (as) taught that night symbolizes both the veils of ignorance enveloping humanity and the fertile time for soulful devotion: *"The believer has no delight greater than the hours of night standing before his Lord in prayer. The verse thus becomes a timeless reminder to trust in divine rhythm, balance, and the ultimate victory of faith.

18.layer1:
In Surah At-Takwir, verse 18, Allah swears by "as-subh idha tanaffas" – the dawn as it breathes – a vivid image evoking the gentle emergence of light dispelling darkness. The term *as-subh* (dawn) refers specifically to the early morning light, while *tanaffas* (breathes) poetically personifies the dawn’s gradual spread, likening it to a living being inhaling and exhaling. This imagery underscores Allah’s mastery over natural cycles and His power to transform darkness into illumination. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights this verse as part of a series of divine oaths (verses 15–18) affirming the Quran’s truth and the inevitability of resurrection, urging reflection on creation’s signs.

Historically, this Meccan surah aimed to awaken the pre-Islamic Arabs to the reality of divine judgment, using phenomena they recognized – like the dawn – to challenge their materialism. The "breathing" dawn symbolises renewal, hope, and the triumph of divine order over chaos. For Shia thought, this aligns with the concept of *ghaybah* (occultation) and the awaited Mahdi, where spiritual darkness will be replaced by the "dawn" of justice. Imam Ali’s teachings in *Nahj al-Balagha* often use dawn as a metaphor for truth emerging after ignorance, resonating with this verse’s themes.

Today, this verse invites Muslims to embrace daily renewal – spiritually, morally, and ethically. Just as dawn marks a fresh start, Muslims are reminded to seek forgiveness (istighfar), engage in morning prayers (Fajr), and approach each day with gratitude (*shukr*) and purpose. The "breathing" dawn also symbolises patience; gradual change, whether personal growth or societal reform, requires steady effort. In a fast-paced world, this verse calls believers to pause, reflect on Allah’s signs in nature, and trust in His timing – a timeless lesson in balancing action with trust (*tawakkul*)
18.layer2:
In Surah al-Takwir (81:18), the Divine oath *"And by the dawn when it breathes"* has been interpreted by classical Shia exegetes through both literal and metaphysical lenses, reflecting the integration of cosmic phenomena with theological principles central to Shia thought. The term *"tanaffas"* (breathes) is pivotal here, evoking imagery of the dawn’s gradual illumination as a living, dynamic process. Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* notes that the "breathing" of dawn refers to its gentle emergence, dispelling darkness incrementally—a metaphor for divine guidance permeating ignorance. This aligns with the Shia emphasis on *hidayah* (guidance) as a gradual, divinely orchestrated unveiling rather than a sudden imposition, mirroring the Imam’s role as a spiritual illuminator.

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this metaphor cosmologically, framing the dawn’s "breath" as a sign of Allah’s creative power and the cyclical renewal inherent in creation—a theme resonant with Shia eschatology. The dawn’s daily rebirth symbolises both the Resurrection (*Qiyamah*) and the awaited reappearance of the Mahdi, whose advent will herald a global spiritual awakening. This interpretation ties the verse to the Shia doctrine of *ghaybah* (occultation) and the transformative justice promised with the Mahdi’s return.

Theologically, the verse underscores the Shia understanding of creation as a *ayat* (sign) pointing to divine sovereignty and the necessity of divinely appointed leadership (*Imamah*). Just as dawn’s light is inseparable from the sun’s essence, the ummah’s guidance is inseparable from the Imams of the Ahl al-Bayt, who embody the "light of prophecy" (*nur al-nubuwwah*). Jurisprudentially, the dawn’s "breath" also alludes to the time of Fajr prayer, reinforcing the integration of cosmic rhythms with ritual worship—a hallmark of Islamic practice. Thus, the verse encapsulates the Shia worldview, where natural phenomena, eschatological hope, and the Imam’s guidance converge as manifestations of divine wisdom.
18.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah At-Takwir’s oath “by the dawn when it breathes” is often explored through lenses of cosmic harmony and human responsibility. Ayatollah Naser Makarim Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, highlights the verse’s emphasis on the rhythmic precision of natural cycles as signs (*ayat*) of divine wisdom. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali extend this, noting how the “breathing” dawn metaphorically mirrors the gradual awakening of human consciousness—a call to align societal progress with ethical and spiritual renewal.  

Scientifically, the “breathing” dawn evokes Earth’s diurnal rhythms, where the interplay of light and atmospheric changes sustains life. Researchers like physicist Dr. Mehdi Golshani, who integrates Quranic themes with cosmology, suggest such verses invite reflection on environmental stewardship—a pressing concern amid climate crises. The dawn’s gentle transition from darkness also resonates with contemporary mental health discourse, symbolising hope amid personal or collective despair, as noted in faith-based counselling frameworks.  

Socially, the verse speaks to movements advocating justice and equity. Scholars such as Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani link the dawn’s renewal to the resilience of marginalised communities, drawing parallels with the Ahlul Bayt’s legacy of perseverance. Interfaith dialogues often cite shared dawn symbolism—from Hindu Ushahin worship to Christian Easter vigils—to foster unity in addressing global poverty or ecological collapse.  

Ultimately, this verse bridges the sacred and the scientific, urging humanity to harmonise material advancement with moral awakening—a timeless message revitalised for an era grappling with existential challenges.
18.layer4:
erse "And by the dawn when it breathes" (81:18) is a profound oath through which Allah swears by the subtle emergence of light that dispels darkness. In the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), this "dawn" symbolizes the radiant guidance of the Imams, whose divine knowledge and wilayah illuminate the hearts of believers, just as the morning light scatters the shadows of night. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, *"The similitude of the Ahlul Bayt is that of the stars: when one sets, another rises"* (Bihar al-Anwar), reflecting how each Imam renews the spiritual dawn for humanity, ensuring truth never fades.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained that the "breathing" dawn signifies the gradual unveiling of divine mercy and wisdom through the Imamah. Just as dawn’s light emerges softly yet transforms the world, the Imams’ teachings penetrate hearts incrementally, awakening souls to truth. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized dawn as a time for intimate supplication, stating, *"In the early hours, seek Allah’s mercy, for it is the hour when blessings descend"* (Bihar al-Anwar). This connects the physical dawn to spiritual vigilance: rising for Fajr prayer, reflecting on the Qur’an, and internalizing the Imams’ teachings.  

Practically, this verse urges believers to align their lives with the "dawn" of divine guidance. Embrace the Imams as your spiritual morning light—let their wisdom dissolve ignorance, their love purify intentions, and their example guide your steps. Strive to awaken your heart daily through remembrance (dhikr), repentance (tawbah), and service, mirroring the dawn’s renewal. As the physical dawn breathes life into the world, so too does allegiance to the Ahlul Bayt breathe eternal purpose into the soul.

تاریخی طور پر ، اس مکہ سرہ کا مقصد اسلامی عربوں کو الہی فیصلے کی حقیقت کے لئے بیدار کرنا تھا ، اور اس کے مادیت کو چیلنج کرنے کے لئے انھوں نے اپنے مادیت کو چیلنج کرنے کے مظاہر کا استعمال کرتے ہوئے۔ "سانس لینے" کا طلوع فجر تجدید ، امید اور افراتفری کے دوران الہی نظم کی فتح کی علامت ہے۔ شیعہ کے خیال کے ل this ، یہ * غیبہ * (جادو) اور منتظر مہدی کے تصور کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، جہاں روحانی اندھیرے کی جگہ انصاف کے "طلوع آفتاب" سے تبدیل ہوگی۔ امام علی کی تعلیمات * نہج البالاگھا * میں اکثر ڈان کو جہالت کے بعد ابھرتے ہوئے سچائی کے استعارے کے طور پر استعمال کرتے ہیں ، اس آیت کے موضوعات سے گونجتے ہیں۔
